Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 03:03PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi allmans, Please don't EVER apologize for asking questions.  That is why we are here!!!!  I'm guessing Tender will be here to give you a really good answer very soon.  Now, every person deals with chemo differently.  My own experience was that I felt fine before chemo, felt horribly weak the first 5 days after chemo, then would start to feel like myself again until the next round.   As for the cancer growing again, I am going to say no to that, but please correct me, ladies, if I am wrong.  I asked my onc. about that, and he basically said that while I am on chemo, it is attacking all the cancer cells in my body.  In my case, I had a grade III cancer, so it took some tweaking to get a chemo that would shrink it as agressively as it had grown, but we got it figured out.   Please, come and ask anytime.  I know this is scary for you as well as your sis.   Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 09:09PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Stacy-I agree that it is NOT too radical a choice.  Most of the time, people who are so eager to talk you out of removing the "good" breast are people who have not had breast cancer.  I was not sure if I wanted to remove my healthy breast at first-I wanted to have another child, and thought that I would regret my choice if I couldn't breast feed a second child.  I debated, researched, and asked everyone.  Finally, I chose to remove both breasts (two days before surgery).  My surgeon told me I was being too radical.  The day after my surgery, I was in horrible pain.  I was in tears-did I make the wrong choice?!  I missed my breasts already, and I hadn't even looked down at my newly flat chest!  That morning, my oncologist came in.  He bluntly told me, "I thought you were making a horrible mistake by having both breasts removed.  I then looked further into your records, and it turns out that you were EXTREMELY at risk for developing cancer in the second breast.  You made the right choice."  I'll never forget that moment.  Ever.  If I could have, I would have jumped up and kissed him.  I just had my two year mastect-a-versary on the 15th.  Like so many of the women here, I don't regret my choice.  Sure, I miss my boobs.  My boobs were a source of frustration for me my entire life (always TOO big), and now they are too small.  My boobs were a huge part of my intimate life.  I was just watching a rerun of "Celebrity Fit Club" and was totally envious of how curvy Tocarra (is that how you spell her name?) looked in her fitted t-shirt.  I used to look like that!  However, I have a husband and a 4 year old son.   I chose to have both breasts removed so I could enjoy both of the men in my life COMPLETELY.  If my other breast were still attached to me, I'd be in a constant state of worry.  Not to say that I don't worry, because Heaven knows I do.  But it is easier now.  Don't let anyone try to strong-arm you into making the choice that THEY are most comfortable with.  You will be amazed at how many people do.  Go with your instinct.  Love and prayers, Deb

Tender, if I am scheduled for U of C after they have looked at the initial scans, will they direct me to a radiologist, or do I need to speak up?  Also, what is your thought on how the it feels smaller and less painful now?  (I had a flare-up of pain and swelling after picking my son up after he fell two days ago).  What are the symptoms of Lymphedema?  The Lymph therapist at my son's therapy office took a peek at my arm and said that the left side is definitely "puffier" than the right.  I never noticed.  We (hubby and I) measured and it was pretty consistently a quarter inch bigger all throughout my arm from shoulder to wrist.  Also, is there any probable connection for me to bring up regarding my...bum issues, and bleeding ulcer?  Could my lymph node swell from that? Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 01:11PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh my gosh-getting the port OUT was a total piece of cake for me!  I am just like you described-a baby.  I also always say, "You'd think after all I've gone through...."  I was worried about going under "twilight" anesthesia.  I wanted to be OUT.  I took an ativan under my tongue that morning.  I was stunned when they said I could wear my SHOES in the room, and have my glasses with me?! What kind of surgery is this?!?!   The doc came in and started digging in to me right away.  I yelled, "I'm still AWAKE!!!!"  I could hear it-that part did freak me out..... Suddenly, the nurse was gently saying, "Debbie? Debbbbieeeee....."  I yelled, "I'm STILL AWAKE!!!!!"  She cracked up and said, "Honey, the surgery has been over for half an hour....."   So, they were right-if you say you need more drugs to keep you calm, you WILL get more drugs!   I was in NO pain afterwards- I felt (and still feel) phantom port pain.  My body still thinks the port is there..... Celebrate that you're getting it out!  What a wonderful surgery to have!  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 11:31AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: This is from a friend of mine who is a zookeeper.....I hope you like the story!  She mentions a book "When Elephants Weep," if you are curious.... Hannah-how are you feeling?  Your Mama Elephants are here for you.  The authors of the book are Jeffrey Masson and Susan McCarthy. It's got quite a bit about elephants, but also about lots of other animals. I am not a wild elephant specialist by any means--actually I'm a giraffe and rhino person. :) So like I said, I probably know the same things you do about wild elephants--how they circle an injured or sick elephant and prop them up and protect them. I've seen some cool videos of elephant births in the wild, where all the females gather around the female in labor and touch her and shield her from any other animals. But other than that, I can't tell you much about wild elephants. When I started at the zoo I'm at now, though, we had two elephants, Lucy and Brittany. They were not a real good match--Lucy was wild-caught as a baby, and we only had an estimate on age--she was between 46 and 50. That's old for an African elephant, and she had really bad arthritis as well as suspected kidney problems and an unpredictable, troublesome digestive tract. Also, because she'd lived through the "bad years" of the zoo industry, she was nervous and moody around people she didn't know well, and was a bit senile besides. (During the 80s, it was commonly accepted that elephants should be beaten when they were "bad". This is NOT accepted any longer, and hasn't been for years, but Lucy had lived through a lot in her time. Just wanted to explain that--I am seriously shocked when I read some of the stuff about how elephants used to be trained. In the system I've been taught, we use a cooperation method of training in which treats are traded for behaviors. I can't imagine inflicting violence on any animal, much less one that could easily squash me.) Anyway, the other elephant, Brit, was 26, a roly poly "retired" circus elephant who was extremely outgoing and had no problem interacting with people. Brittany had come to live at the zoo when Lucy's former companion had died. Like I said, they were not a great match. Brit would try to play with Lucy and Lucy would just get scared and then they'd both be upset. Brit would steal Lucy's food. Brit would steal treats, she would steal toys, whatever she could get away with, because Lucy was so old and passive. And Brittany couldn't have many toys to begin with, because most toys scared Lucy too much. Anyway, Lucy's health wasn't good when I met her, and within a year she was going downhill fast. She fell in the yard one day and couldn't get up. Healthy elephants lay down and get up all the time, but old and/or sick elephants often don't have the muscle strength to heave their own weight back up if they lay down or fall. Anyway, Lucy fell in the yard. The keepers (I was off that day, so I only heard about this) spent over half an hour trying to get Brittany to come into the barn (usually a 30 second process) because Brit wouldn't leave Lucy. She was hovering over Lucy, touching her and trying to protect her, and Brittany's energy was sky-high hyper, just flapping her ears and waving her trunk and all riled up. Whenever the keepers would get Brit to even take a couple steps toward the barn, Lucy would move or groan and Brit would rush back over to her and stand over her and touch her with her trunk and flap her ears, all wild-eyed. Anyway, the keepers finally got Brit to go in the barn, and they picked Lucy back up with a crane. It was on the news and everything. Lucy never seemed to get completely over that, mentally or physically, and Brittany started being more careful around Lucy. She didn't steal food and always seemed to be watching Lucy. She didn't touch Lucy a lot during that time, but I wonder if that was because their relationship had never been super-solid in the first place, or if she knew Lucy was hurting. (Or both?) In any case, a couple months later Lucy fell again, in her stall. The decision was made to euthanize her--actually the decision had been made earlier that if she fell again, she would be euthanized, because nobody wanted to see her go through the agony of being hoisted up and forced to go on with all the health issues she had. Brittany was in another stall during the euthanasia, but after Lucy was gone Brittany was allowed to come in and be with the body. She stood over Lucy for a long time, but you could tell she knew Lucy was already dead. She would touch her gently with her trunk and then just stand there, kind of drooping, and then she'd touch her really gently again, like she was sniffing and petting her at the same time. Then she'd just stand there and stare at Lucy and her trunk and ears and whole posture just sagged. (This was the point at which every human in the room was crying, too--Brittany's posture was more expressive than anything anyone could have said.) Anyway we let her stay with Lucy as long as she wanted, which ended up being about 45 minutes. Then she wandered back into her own stall, and then we sent her out into the yard, since Lucy had to be necropsied in her stall and that would've been way too traumatic for Brittany to see or smell. Brit lived by herself for three months, and during those three months, she was the most needy animal I have ever met. She solicited attention CONSTANTLY from all of us, and threw tantrums randomly and swayed (a lot of elephants sway as a self-comforting gesture when they're bored or anxious) and was generally pathetically needy. I felt terrible for her, but I have to admit that after awhile she was getting on my nerves, too, which makes me feel bad to even admit, but oh well, it's true. In any case, after three months we found out we could get another elephant from a zoo in Texas. Her name is Ruth and her only companion had died a year or two before. Ruth is the same age as Brit and can play and interact with her on her own level. Ruthie and Brittany have been together now for two and a half years, and I have to tell you, even though I adored Lucy, it's so much fun to see the relationship between Brit and Ruth, because it's so much richer and I would think, more satisfying for Brit than what she and Lucy had. Brit and Ruth do almost everything together, and sometimes they bug eachother, and have their little tiffs, and then they're leaning on eachother and sharing food or playing in the mud together or whatever. It's really nice to see. But if Brit could protect and comfort and mourn like that for Lucy, who she didn't even get along with too well, what would she be like if anything happened to a companion that she loved? Anyway, that is my elephant story. Not sure if it's what you had in mind, but it's some of the most striking animal emotions I've ever witnessed.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 07:53PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh, ladies.....this has me totally in flashback mode....some comments made me laugh, some made me smile in a melancholy mode, others made me misty-eyed.  I had chemo in November of 2005-through May of 2006.  My hair was a part of my identity.  I was always known as the one with the totally thick, auburn and straight hair.  It was down to the middle of my back, and I was really happy with my appearance.  Suddenly, I was faced with the fact that I'd be bald.  Okay....I accepted that after a few days, and assured myself that it would happen after I had my simple little cancer lumpectomy (this isn't how I feel about breast cancer now, but at diagnosis, I was going through the MAJOR denial of it all, and thought this would be a little bump in my life).  I was then told I needed pre-op chemo because my tumor was huge.  OMG.  I was going to be bald waaaaay before I was ready.  My hair started coming out 15 days after chemo started, and I sat through Thanksgiving dinner with clumps of hair mixed into my turkey.  I had my head shaved that following Monday, and cried like a baby.  It was probably just as emotional for me as it was to have been diagnosed.  I'll never forget-I couldn't, no wouldn't look at myself as the hairdresser wrapped my hanky-hat on my head.  She urged my dh to tell me how beautiful he was, and I will never forget how he looked at me and sort of blurted the words out.  I couldn't make myself go bald for about a week at home.  I forced myself to go to lunch at the most popular restaurant in town the next day.  I wore my crisp, white hanky hat and felt like the world stopped to watch me walk around the restaurant.  The first time I showed my son, he was playing.  I said, "Honey, I have to show you something,"  I pulled off the HOT hat I was wearing, and my son giggled, rubbed my head, and kept playing.  He sure put it into perspective for me!  Oh, the stupid comments about, "How you must save money on shampoo!"  "You must be ready soooo fast in the mornings!" and, like so many of you said, "It's just hair."  Nope, it's not.  It's everything.  It is the proof that you look like you feel inside.  I have a picture just like Mary Lou posted of myself, staring into the camera, with my bald head.  I made sure I had a prop (my son) so I could detract from my shiny scalp.  Yes, I have hair again, but I kind of resent this hair. It is insane, not the same color, and certainly not the same texture.  I spent way too much money getting it straightened and was delighted with it for about a week.  Now I hate it again.  It's chemo hair, and it is like a scarlet letter emblazoned on my head!  Oh, you've all brought me back.  I salute you, my sisters!  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2008 02:21PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi Debi, Tender is a great source for the true medical questions like yours.  I can answer them from the "patient" viewpoint.   My opinion is to PUSH and PUSH again until you get an answer.  So many of the women here (myself included) can probably agree that we started our journey with a lump that we were told was nothing.  Mine was first mammo'd 3.5 years before dx.  I was only 31 at dx., so of course I would get the brush-off.  The lump that turned out to be cancer was indeed in the same exact area that I had checked out 3.5 years prior.   If only I knew to push.  So many what if's with cancer....what if I pushed and got more opinions??!  You are doing the right thing by seeking out answers.  My lump went back towards my chest wall, and ended up between 7-10 cm.  They'll never know, because by the time it was dx'd. it was so huge I needed pre-op chemo.  Oh, and so many women who were told it was nothing on the mammo, were dx'd with a sono, and probably vice-versa, too.  Mine was very clear as to what an issue it was when I got a breast MRI.  On the surface, they thought it was approx. 2 cm.  You could only feel it when I was lying down, with my arm up over my head.  You could "sort of" feel it with my arm down, but it was questionable.  It was rock-hard when lying down, but standing up, my big breasts were so squishy I couldn't find it.  Oh, and as for the tech....my gosh, when will they get techs in the rooms with a little decency.  This is our LIFE we are dealing with, and if the techs have no respect for that, they are really making an unbearable situation all the worse.  I say report a tech that does that to you and ask for a new one.  Good luck, and please let us know.   Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 08:15PM - edited Aug 17, 2008 08:17PM by whoopsiedoodles Dearest ML- I have been dealing with chronic fatigue since the moment I began chemo (when we met 3 years ago this November!).  Now, I have MS also, and that is supposed to be a SE of that as well.  However, I DID NOT suffer from chronic fatigue before cancer came running into my life.  There are times now that I could easily fall asleep on command.  I feel so lethargic, and when my little Daniel sometimes wants to play something like "lets go ride bikes, Mommy!" I want to make excuses and talk the poor kid out of it.  I have to remind myself that it isn't his fault Mommy doesn't feel good, and he doesn't deserve to not play just because of my "ailments."  The fatigue and pain just keep lingering in my body, and I feel like I went from an active 31 year old woman to about a 90 year old woman trapped inside my body.  The fatigue is frustrating, and my poor husband has actually said, "I just want my wife back."  That breaks my heart.  " I want my life back,"  I want to cry out to him.  It isn't his fault, either.  I have to force myself to do these things, when all I want to do is just sit.  It's hard, isn't it?  EDIT TO ADD: about feeling like we look lazy.....I sometimes feel like I have to explain what I accomplished during the day to my husband, and why it isn't as much as either of us liked.  I hate thinking he thinks I'm lazing around the house all day.  I know he isn't really thinking such things, but I feel guilty and sluggish.  Ick.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 10:31AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Okay, it didn't work!  I just cut and pasted instead.  Deb  All, Thanks for all the Great Vibes!  Deb had Chemo yesterday and we spoke to Dr. Kelly.  He would have liked to seen more progress (Duh wouldn't we all!)  but says the fact that she is progressing is very good.  He also did not feel this would be a permanent thing.   Today, she seems to be feeling good for the day after chemo, so we went for our walk.  She did great but I decided it was time to head back as I was getting cold! (It dropped below 0 last night & was about 8 degrees at walk time (1:30pm).  Time to get out my winter boots & wear gloves.  I also got a copy of deb's blood work numbers.   She is due for a week off next week but I wanted to make sure things were not getting too low.  I have not kept up on these things as much as I probably should since when I scanned the numbers a curious number jumped out at me.  I never knew that they actually rated "BUN"(s?).  This begs the question. How do you improve your "BUN"(s?)/"CREAT"(ive?) ratio???????????  Is this a dance move?   Oh well, I'll just keep walking.......as Deb alway says, John's Ignorance is Bliss.    Also, Deb's appetite came back the last couple of days. She's been eating very well.   This afternoon, she had just finished her lunch. A sandwich, milk, her favorite chips, fresh veggies, and some orange slices....Well rounded I thought.  I then gave her some more chocolate milk & went into the other room to change the laundry.  I came back a minute later & she had one chipmunk cheek.  A week or so ago she was not swallowing without being told so I naturally told her to swallow.   She refused!  So I told her to open her mouth & there was the plastic lid to the milk jug. I paniced & got her to spit it out.  Naturally,  I gave her more to eat!   All in all though,  I think it's a great sign!  Blessings to all & Thanks again for the Prayers & Well Wishes! John

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 03:31PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Kalyla, You can ask for a script for Gabapentin/Neurontin to help the neuropathy.  Taxol, it seems for me, was the chemo to give me the most residual effects-it was far easier to bear, yet the hardest to recover from!  I have MS, too, so my Neurontin was already the one drug I had been taking when dx'd.  It really does help with the Neuropathy-it does take some time to go away with some of the women, so it is up to you if you want to just grin and bear it or get some relief.  It can make you sleepy in the beginning, but my body adjusted to it very quickly.  Love and prayers, Deb PS-CONGRATS on finishing!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 04:03PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hey Nancy, I am almost 2 years out of chemo, but I have to chime in on this thread, because I am a total foodie.  HUGE foodie.  I agree with the pennies flavor to everything, but I just had issue with flavor overall.   Water tasted like poison to me.  Strawberries, and other fresh fruit tasted just plain awful-it all had a very....heavy?....taste.  The flavor of fruit just hung there for hours.  When I was off of chemo after about a month, all I ate for the next 3 months (no exaggeration, either!) was fresh fruit salad, more fresh fruit salad, vegetarian corn dogs (just the thought of corn dogs made me ill during tx.), and enchiladas.  It was heaven after 7 months of toxic tastic food.  All I could handle during chemo was the bland but then delicious flavor of carb-goodness.   Egg noodles, plain pasta, potatoes of any sort, bread of any sort, rice.   I drank gallons of Crystal Light, because the tart lemonade was light enough to not hang in my mouth for hours, but strong enough to cover the flavor of the poison, I mean water.  My mouth just plain hurt, and that really affected food, too.  I had so many mouth sores that when I thought I could eat chips and salsa on an off-week of chemo, I nearly died.  I yelped, "My heavens, is this extra spicy?!?!" and my hubby thought I was nuts.   To this day, the thought of certain foods I ate on chemo make my stomach churn.  I will NEVER again eat a strawberry smoothie, a vanilla Frappucino from Starbucks, or a blackened chicken salad from Applebees.  I cower in fear from garlic bread, and Bertolli's Chicken Parmesan, because I ate those the first day of chemo, and while it was a favorite before that, I could hardly eat a bite.  It broke my heart to not finish something I would gladly polish off my husbands portion if he would've let me!!!  Ay-about 6 months after chemo, I suddenly realized that the chemo diet was going into reverse, and I started to inhale all my old favorites again.  That was one tiny blessing in disguise, too.  I got skinny on chemo..... Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 01:06AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Kelly, That truly is the worst moment-telling your child that Mommy has something bad inside her.  My son was only 15 months old when I was diagnosed.  I did tell him, and the poor kid accompanied me to practically every cancer appointment I had for the next two years.  I really didn't know if he understood.  Now that he is 4, he says, "Mommy!  Look-a pink ribbon.  Do they have breast cancer?  What is that over there?  A funeral home?  Is that where Heaven is?  When will you have cancer again? Look, that man has no hair.  You used to not have hair!"  The observations just keep coming.  My heart breaks when he asks about death and "when" I will have cancer again.  I had hoped I shielded him from the terror in my eyes, the worry in my voice.  Nope.  Our kids hear and absorb so much more than we could ever expect-at any age.  I know we all handle it differently.  I know some Mommies here choose to NOT tell their kids.  Others feel it is a necessity.  My feeling is that either way, they will know something isn't the same in their lives.  Now that you have hit this point, it will get easier.  Not EASY, but easier.  Now that you have told them, you can share this experience honestly.  Fitz (as always) really hit it on the head when she said that even under the circumstances they will still make you mad.  SO TRUE!  My son can make me insane, and I stop and remind myself that I need to soak in EVERY moment with my baby-even the crappy ones when he is screaming, crying, and yelling, "You're a BAD Mommy" (like today, when he didn't get to play for 5 more minutes as he had hoped).  It does get easier, honest.  We are all here for you along the way.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 10:15AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi shocked, No, you aren't ignorant, and no you aren't the only one to not know.  There is no way that you could have known until you are thrown into the vicious "you might have cancer!" game.  I had a 7-10 cm tumor at the age of 31, and had been doing BSE's, and even had a mammo 2 years prior for the EXACT area which my tumor was diagnosed.  I had JUST had a gyno exam in the middle of July, and my tumor was not able to be felt.   Come September, my tumor was massive, and my left breast was noticeably different than the right.  This is just the nature of the beast, and what you are feeling is SOOOO normal.  I think a LOT of us have gone through the self-blame process, but in the end (diagnosis or no diagnosis of cancer), you realize that you have been doing your best and will continue to do your best.  No matter what, you are doing the right thing now by getting it checked out and taken care of.  At this point, IF this is cancer you are dealing with, you WILL do what you need to do and you will NOT be ignorant about it.  Don't do that to yourself.  You are clearly an intelligent woman.  Come here for whatever needs you have.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 02:28AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: It sounds like this might be your first one?  Well, that coupled with an MRI that will give you some sort of important piece of information,  I can't say I blame you for wanting to scream.  Scream all you want BEFORE you go into the MRI, for certain.  It's really not so bad.  I have had countless MRI's done; brain, lumbar/cervical, breast.  I always keep my eyes closed.  It helps me not be so aware of the close surroundings.  I tend to get groggy (with all of the loud noises, it's hard to believe!!), but I don't fight it.  If I want to sleep, then so be it!!  Last time, I was in a very light sleep that yielded bizarre dreams.  If the groggies don't win, I pray.  I pray, pray, pray.  If you are not a praying woman, this obviously isn't the choice for you.  However, it gives you excellent time to meditate on your life.  It's not so bad.  Honest  Let us know, ok?  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 03:14PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh gheesh....add me to this little club of broken thryoids.  I've GAINED 18 pounds since mid November.  My Dad died very suddenly then, and I thought I was stress eating.   Well, I went on Jenny Craig and STILL WAS GAINING!!!!   My feet are always cold.  My eyebrow (left side only!) has disappeared!  My skin is so dry it's disgusting.  I'm SOOOOOO tired and lethargic, sometimes I can hardly move.  I'm SOOOOOOO dizzy, sometimes I can hardly move.  My aches and pains are never ending.  I've been voicing all of this to my docs, and not ONE has said, "Oh, let's get your thyroid checked..." Instead, I was put on massive doses of Nortriptyline (gheesh, make me more tired, why don't you??), given lousy pain meds (partially my issue because I begged to get off of vicoden), and yelled at for gaining weight.   I had to go to a prompt care place for this, because since we have moved, I can't seem to get into a doctor to save my life.  I have an appointment set up in May for a new patient visit, but couldn't wait that long.  I was therefore chastised for coming to a prompt care, because "it should be for more immediate needs," instead of being taken care of as expected.   Oh, so I still haven't gotten the official results yet.  My old roomie from college got her thyroid checked the same day as I did and got her results the next day.  It's day 10 for me.   This sucks!

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 03:44PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh, Kazzyann....your story sounds so strikingly similar to what I had experienced with my Dad exactly one year ago.  My Dad's health was going downhill, he hadn't told a soul (he lived alone as a widowed husband), my brother lived blocks away, I lived an hour away.....I had been calling him to invite him for Thanksgiving (knowing he would have said no, anyway).  He wasn't answering the phone or calling me back, so I called the police to check on him.  That is when we discovered that his belly was enormous.  He had the very end stages of cirrhosis.  He was completely confused and had no idea what was happening.  We got him to the hospital, but he died three days later.  My heart simply broke as I read your message.  My message to you is that YOU ARE NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR MUM.   She was sick, but it was not your responsibility to be sure she took care of herself.  If you do that to yourself, you will go perfectly crazy as a result.  Don't blame yourself for this.  As for the family issues, unfortunately those seem to come with such territory (although never intentionally).  Try not to say anything if hurtful words are being hurled at you.  Those will only hurt the situation more.  I know it sounds impossible, but you must try.  This is not an easy situation, and I am so deeply sorry that your family is experiencing this.  Love your Mum and be with her when you can.  Feel free to PM me if you need.  Love and prayers, Deb
Posts.Title: Just been told my mum has weeks to live kazzyann TorchSong

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 04:02PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Isn't that interesting how they all do it differently?   I'd bet that if all the women diagnosed that are members here responded, we'd all have had different approaches to the tests we received.   I think that my onc. ordered the bilateral breast MRI and x-ray/bone scan because he had worried of presence in my nodes.  I will tell you this:  One of the women here said something very wise the other day.  "It is what it is."  She had just been diagnosed with mets after 3 years of no evidence of disease.  Not an ounce of worry will change what is in your Mom's tests and results.  You all have the right and need to mourn the loss of the life you once knew as "normal," but there will be a point when you will all suddenly realize that it is time to fight like mad.  It is scary, and the fact that we are all different and there is no "set in stone" explanation of what is going to happen is very unsettling.  However, cancer is NOT a death sentence.  Please don't forget that.  Also, encourage your Mom to come here if she needs something, too!  Love and prayers, Deb
Posts.Title: lump size and progression-really need answers cshamber CAZ

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 10:33PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh honey.   This is one of the hardest things about cancer.  At least it was for me.  After chemo, surgery, and rads, I felt anything but beautiful.  I also felt like my poor husband was thinking of me more as his patient than his wife and mate.  I wish I could say our intimacy just jumped back on track right away, but it took a lot of work for the both of us.  We were suddenly without my breasts, which were a HUGE part of our physical connection.  I strongly urge you to check out the mojo thread.  That is a place where so many of us go to get ideas and support as we deal with the physical and emotional changes cancer can bring to our lives.  It has helped me tremendously.  I took quite a while before I would have sex without my shirt on.  I covered up with my t-shirt, a cami, a nightie, whatever.   I hated it at first, but it was so important to me to continue to give that to my husband.  He was a little unsure at first, but we stumbled through it together.  He still goes for my breasts quite a bit, and it is hard not to pull away.  He has no way of knowing that I have some sensation in one spot but not the other.  I try to just lose myself in the closeness and forget that I feel "broken."   It is so hard, I know.  This is going to be tough, but you have got to do this together, and you have to talk about it.  You HAVE to.  This isn't going to go away or change-you are different now than you once were.  And, remember, it may feel like your husband isn't "loving" you, but he is going through the changes right alongside you-just as an onlooker, yes, but nonetheless he is watching his love go through something he can't protect her from.  He is scared, too.  Love each other.  That is all you can do.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 03:18PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi there! I know this is so scary and stressful for you.  Try to take a deep breath and slow down a bit.  Nancy gave a very nice answer-I'm just going to add a few of my thoughts..... The straightforward answer to your question is yes, the cancer tumor may be tiny, but still have been able to spread.  If you look at most of our "tag lines," it will show our diagnosis.  Even almost three years later, I still marvel at how some of us have rather huge tumors, but are only classified at stage II (my diagnosis),and others have teensy tumors and are stage IV.  Cancer is so ruthless, it doesn't care how it affects each of us, and unfortunately, we are all different as a result.  I always would have preferred a straightforward answer like in the "What to Expect When You Are Expecting" books.  It could be "What to expect with Cancer" instead.  Ugh.  Of course, there is no way to know it until the docs step in and do a multitude of tests.  Nancy was right with the CT and PET scans as something that is done.  In addition, there can also be a chest x-ray (to check for lung mets), a bilateral breast MRI to see if the other breast is healthy, a bone scan if there is thought that mets are present in the bones.  You and your Mom will be dealing with test after test after test for a long time, and it will be hard.  However, these are the tests that monitor your Mom to be sure there were no stray cancer cells that broke free to travel elsewhere in your body.  Chemo isn't a walk in the park, but it isn't impossible.  Don't worry if she has to do chemo, because it isn't like they make it look in the movies.  Look at Robin Roberts, she worked through her chemo, like so many other women.  Radiation was better tolerated in my situation, but again, we are all different.  Hang in there, and please come here whenever you have a question or worry.  Chances are, someone here will have gone through something just like it and can help you out.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 02:40PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi Vanilla, Yes, I think a bunch of us can attest to having the hives issue.   I also think that the hives occur for a number of reasons.  The first one is of course an allergic reaction to the tx., and I would recommend letting her onc. know about it asap.  The other one is an allergic reaction to the anti-nausea meds.  I had a very huge, very scary, very bizarre allergic reaction to compazine, and thought my skin was going to burst into flames, and I lost control of my arms and legs.  I was instructed to take Benadryl, and was fine within the hour.   Another reason to call the onc. asap!  The final one for me was hand and foot syndrome.  This wasn't hives, but my hands and feet were practically purple they were so irritated, and they HURT.  I could hardly function.  The good news is that it won't last forever, but if she tells her doc. she can get relief from the issues as soon as possible.   Good luck, and you are a precious daughter to care so much.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 09:56AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Oh Honey, Please, please PLEASE don't try to be a "Superwoman."  A mastectomy (bilateral or unilateral) can HURT.  I was out of commision as per my surgeon for 6 weeks.  I wasn't supposed to lift a blasted thing other than a drink or toothbrush. After about 4 weeks, I was feeling better, and able to move my arms more and more.  I had to do my ROM stretches and I HATED them.  My son has CP, and we have to stretch his poor little limbs each day.  I never understood what he went through until my recovery.  Did you have a bilateral or unilateral?  Did your doctor give a recommendation yet?  I do think that your employers should be pretty darned understanding about this.  It's not that you are playing a cancer card, you are HEALING.  Is there a sick leave bank?  My husband's office donated days to him so he could be home to take care of me as well as our then 2 year old.  I am sure that the other ladies have something to add.  I just want to gently encourage you to NOT push yourself.  Be well.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 09:58PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi Lisa, I don't mind you asking at all.  I was diagnosed at age 31, and I turn 34 TOMORROW!!!  I never thought I'd be delighted to get older, but I am thrilled.  Yes, waiting for anything that has to do with your cancer is the hardest time ever.  However, keep in mind that we are all SOOOO different.  You can't compare yourself completely to the other women, because we all respond differently to tx.  I had a huge tumor, but I was stage IIa/IIb.  Others have a tiny tumor and are stage IV.  You'll make yourself nuts if you compare notes too much.  Carol1949-I had taxol.  It was a BREEZE for me in comparison to the AC, and I had it with carboplatin.  However, I will say that taxol seems to be the culprit (or so I am told) for my constant pain, and it was two years ago that I finished treatment.  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 12:38AM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi Erika, I had a love/hate relationship with my port.  I HATED how it felt.  I just KNEW there was a foreign "thing" in my chest, and I still cringe when my son goes near it.  I even have phantom port feelings (got mine out in October).  My hubby sat and poked at it the day I got it.....UGH!!  He was fascinated, I was miserable.  I LOVED my port because it made chemo a breeze.  I had NO problems (once or twice, I had to lay on my side to help the flow), and for me, blood draws were a breeze!  I'd ask other docs to use it, but they don't have the supplies at regular offices to do it (usually).  I will say this-for me, port flushes made my head very light.  It happened the first time and freaked me out.  I expected it from that point, and if I just talked to my port nurse incessantly while she accessed it, it would help the "I'm gonna faint" feeling pass.  You're doing great.  Keep coming here when you need to vent.  Love and prayers, Deb
Posts.Title: i got my port today ekenny315 cupcake7

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2008 03:51PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Hi cupcake!  Like I said in my post, I had a love/hate relationship with my port, but I will never regret having had one.  My veins are always collapsing, and I always need a butterfly needle.  Goodness, when my son was born 4 years ago, I had toxemia and HELLP syndrome-they had to draw blood constantly to check my platelets.  My arms were one giant bruise, and they had to move to my FEET!  Yikes!   So, that being said, I put in a solid YES vote on getting a port.  Granted, other women have had not happy results, and there are risks involved.  Let us know, ok?  Love and prayers, Deb

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 07:32PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: Ladies- Our Stephanie posted this the other day (sorry, no sense of time, not sure of what day off-hand), and I don't think many of us saw it.  It's amazing...... Refreshing Words of Faith, Hope and Love - The Letter Life begins with faith, hope and love. Is it ironic that when we leave this place we leave drinking from the same cup? God is able my friend ; believe it until the end.  Despite the prognosis or the report.  We are more than conquerors.  As I sit here and type a letter for you, I think back on my journey from stage 1 to 4. This letter is not to give light to your path, for only the Lord should do that. But this letter is from my soul to yours to give credence to the call of the brave. Only the brave stand to look breast cancer square in the eyes and fight it for what it is. It is a disease that tries to destroy families, communities and nations.  The worst thing you can ever give a women fighting for her life is a pink ribbon.  Instead give her permission to be optimistic; give her a crown to cover her head; give her friendship that's tested, tried and true. This letter can't be a torch to pass on because this relay must end. This letter I write to you as my life ends and your journey begins is my cup to refresh you. Begin your journey knowing that God is able only if you allow Him to reign supreme in your life.  There above the cancer, above the test results and above your fears. God is Almighty and only He can eradicate breast cancer. This letter is your authorization to enforce faith, evoke your rights as a child of God and to claim your reward.  God is able.  stephanie "The girl who became emotionally distraught, and wavered at each new set of circumstances is now grown up, a woman who has learned to rely on God's sovereignty" Joni Eareckson Tada

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 06:32PM whoopsiedoodles wrote: My hubby was given donated vacation time from work and was able to stay home with me for 6 weeks.  We had a then 2 year old boy, and there was no way I'd have been able to do it without him there.  I felt lousy and immobile for the first 2 weeks, but after that I began to regain my range of motion and comfort.  All I can say is NOT TO PUSH IT.  You will have had some mega-surgery and need to heal.  That being said, you still get up and get around as much as your body can handle.  (gee-conflicting message?).   Do you go to church?  My church family was amazing and came to watch our son so my hubby could have a break, and they'd bring us meal after meal.  They also cleaned our house for us.  It kinda sucks, but you do heal and you do move on.   PS-there is a great preparing for mast. thread....I'm going to bump it up for you...... Love and prayers, Deb
